title: Keybase /AppData/Local/Keybase/uploadtemps folder stores pasted photos
vulnerability_information:
During research, I had noticed that Keybase does not adequately clear the cache and some residual files can be viewed, with no form of encryption on the files. In addition, these pasted photos remain even after clearing the containing chat. Not all of the pasted photos remain, so it's unclear what makes some stay within the cache while others are effectively cleared.

I haven't seen any CVE identifier, so I have requested a CVE-ID from MITRE.

**Replication**
1. On a Windows machine, navigate to C:\Users\yourusername\AppData\Local\Keybase\uploadtemps
2. Note that some directories remain and that inside of the directories, you may find that some files are here, particularly image pastes.
F1150615
F1150618

## Impact

This is problematic because Keybase is supposed to be privacy centric. An attacker that gains access to a victim machine can potentially obtain sensitive data through through gathered photos, especially if the user utilizes Keybase frequently. A user, believing that they are sending photos that can be cleared later, may not realize that occasionally pasted photos are not cleared from the cache and may send photos of credentials, etc, to friends or may even send other sensitive data. The photos then can be stored insecurely on a case-by-case basis.

activities.message: So far this is vetted on Windows. Checking other platforms soon.

This vulnerability also exists on MAC, it was also discovered that a lot more media is available through the "Cache" and "uploadtemps" directories on both MAC and Windows. 

For example, on MAC - media that has been exploded or deleted is cached on the user's device: F1150780
F1150784

Affected Directories Caching Content:

**Windows**
C:\Users\usernamehere\AppData\Local\Keybase\uploadtemps
C:\Users\usernamehere\AppData\Roaming\Keybase\Cache

**MAC**
/Users/usernamehere/Library/Caches/Keybase/uploadtemps
~/Library/Application Support/Keybase/Cache

MITRE has validated the reports and assigned a CVE Number:
CVE-2021-23827
Thanks for the report, this sounds like a bug, we're investigating.

I patiently await your response. I would disagree that it is a "low" however, as the entire premise of E2EE is ensuring that conversations maintain secure and unviewable by third parties. Users put trust in the platform - which includes their uploaded media and as it stands, a lot of media can be recovered between the Cache and Uploadtemps folders.

Thanks.  The `uploadtemps` folder is what we're thinking of as a bug (for pasted images), but we're not finding any misbehavior with the `Cache` dir so far -- the files in that dir are encrypted, and are intentionally stored.  Can you tell us if you've been able to find any *unencrypted* files in the `Cache` dir?

For severity, I went with CVSSing it out, assuming that there's low confidentiality loss because we're only dealing with this case of pasted images rather than all attachments.  Would be happy to update the CVSS if that understanding's incorrect.

CVSS:3.0/AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N

Yes I have, take a look. Some of the files that are in this folder are photos that have long since been exploded or deleted in previous conversations:
F1153986
In fact, I found many instances of this. I would be happy to give you an exact count - but it was far higher than the uploadtemps folder paste issue.

Hi @cjb -- even though I found many instances of uploaded attachments that can be recovered, I haven't been able to determine if it's all of them, or closer to 50%-75% of them.

If you make a determination that it's all of them, please let me know otherwise I would also rate this as:
CVSS:3.0/AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N

[More privacy impact related than a vulnerability, but yes even if it's a "low" vuln I think the privacy impact gives it warrant for a med-high]

Thank you! Let me know if you need anything.
Thanks! We've been able to reproduce the Cache dir behavior too now. We're working on a fix for both issues, and we'll get back to you soon with an update on severity and bounty.
Thank you!
Hello @cjb -- any further testing that I can assist with? I'm also hoping to get on the same page for the intended patching timelines, disclosures for the CVE notices, etc.

I think we're good!  We're preparing a release with fixes for both uploadtemps and Cache now, and I'm hoping to finalize severity and bounty this week and then start talking with you about coordinating disclosure.

The new release will clear out files that should have been deleted the first time around, and we'd like to give plenty of time for clients to accept this new update before disclosure.

Thanks!
Sounds good, thanks again for the update!
Thanks for the excellent report!  We'll let you know when the fixed build is released publicly, probably within a week.

Perfect. Once the build is released, let me know and I will do a writeup that you can review, and once given the okay I will put it on my website and we can publish this Hackerone report to use as the second reference in the CVE for submission to MITRE. Does that work with you?

Thanks for the bounty!
It looks like the patches have been pushed out on all of the platform. Requesting permission to disclose this report, to use for MITRE References & for my writeup.
No disclosure yet, please -- we haven't pushed out the new release yet, and even after it is released, we would prefer to wait until most users have applied the update before disclosing.
Okay, when is your proposed timeline of public release?
I first reported this vulnerability roughly 17 days ago. Please provide your intended no-later than date for a universal patch and for disclosure to the public.

Hi, an update:

* The fixed release (5.6.0 on Windows and Mac, 5.6.1 on Linux) was released Saturday Jan 23.  It disables both of these cache directories (Cache and uploadtemps) and removes any cached files from them at app launch time.

* We'd like to give users 30 days to apply the update, which puts disclosure on Mon Feb 22.

* We'd like to review your CVE and blog post whenever you're able to share a private draft.

Thank you!
I will work on the writeup and share something with you this upcoming weekend, being that we are set for Feb 22. Plenty of time. Thank you for the response.
Hey @cjb we have reviewed our findings and modified the CVE writeup to attune better with the situation. Please see the attached and let us know what you think.
Thanks!  We're working on writing up feedback and should be able to share it within a few days.
Sounds good, thank you.

Hi, here's our feedback:

> Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor (CWE-200)

We think "Cleartext Storage in a File or on Disk (CWE-313)" is a better choice, both because it's more specific, and because someone who can read private files in your home directory is not an unauthorized actor -- they necessarily have your user account's authorization already.

> Line 1: Keybase Client, Windows, macOS, Android, iPhone

Android and iPhone were not affected, but Linux was:
Line 1: Keybase desktop client for Windows, macOS, Linux.

> Line 2: Versions <= 5.22

Line 2: Versions < 5.6.0 on Windows and macOS, < 5.6.1 on Linux

> Description: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor in Keybase Client for Windows, macOS, Android & iPhone allows attacker to obtain ...

Description: Cleartext Storage In a File in Keybase desktop clients for Windows, macOS, Linux allows an attacker who can read private files owned by a user to obtain ..

And then for the writeup:

> Keybase is known as an End-to-End Encryption (EE2E) Communication
Application. In non-technical terms, this means that conversations between individuals or
groups within the app shouldnt be stored, anywhere.

Hm, that doesn't sound right -- E2EE apps store your conversations so you can read them later, if they haven't been deleted.  Perhaps consider changing "shouldn't be stored on disk" to "shouldn't be persistently stored unencrypted on disk"?  (I know you were trying for non-technical.)

Please could you also add this text describing remediation?

> Keybase addressed this issue on January 23, 2021 in versions 5.6.0 for Windows and macOS, and 5.6.1 for Linux. By updating to the latest version of Keybase, any unintentionally cached files are removed. No other action is required.

One more question, is the writeup inside the PDF what will be the text of the blog post, or are they separate?

Please let us know if you disagree with any of these, and we'd love to see a final version once it's ready.  Thank you!

Those are changes we can happily make. They will be made tonight.

To answer your question, the PDF had the writeup for the blog post and the official MITRE writeup. Anything that will be written by us was included in that.

Every point that you had mentioned has now been addressed. Please review, keeping in mind that this line of text represents the start of the blog writeup, "Writeup [To be used as the official Reference]" - while everything above the line is the official modifications of the previous submission that will be sent to MITRE for review.

If everything looks good, do you still propose a release date of February 22? I see no issue with an earlier release if it's patched, however as the Bug Bounty Program manager it's your call.

Thanks!  There's a "Versions  5.6.0 on Windows and macOS" which should be a "Versions < 5.6.0 on Windows and macOS" in the CVE section.

Yes, we'd like to stick with Feb 22, still waiting for some clients to apply the available upgrade.
All fixed and sounds great. Thank you for the help!
